utterances: How are you?
I'm good.
So, how did you watch the election results?
I watched them on different news stations.
I watched Fox, CNN, and CNBC.
And you told me in our piece that aired on Monday that you might have some disagreements on election night with your conservative father, who's voting for McCain.
How did that pan out?
He ended up actually voting for Obama, to my surprise.
He was a little upset with McCain, just because he feels as though Obama will have a better plan for the economic problems, and that affects my dad more, so...
So, what was it like that night when the result was know, and Barack Obama was declared the new president.
It was pretty cool.
Like, it was a mix of feelings.
Like, we all kind of saw it coming after Ohio closed, and after, you know, Obama won Pennsylvania and all the other swing states, but it was pretty cool knowing that, like, we were living in history.
Now, we just heard from your teacher, Mr. Mathew, that you're to write a letter to President-elect Obama.
What will you write?
Do you know?
I haven't really given it much thought because I just found out that we were doing that when you found out...
Just now, in other words?
Yeah, he hadn't told us.
He just like, when he - when he told you, we found out.
So, I haven't really given it much thought, but...
If you could say, you know, please focus on this one thing, what would it be?
The economy, definitely.
Right.
Your classmate Heidi Reyes (ph)?
Is she there as well?
Yeah, she's here.
Could I talk to her?
Uh-huh.
Thanks.
Heidi, the phone's for you.
Hello.
Hi, Heidi.
Hi.
And you were the lone McCain supporter in the group.
That's right.
What are you thinking today?
You know, right after realizing that Barack Obama was going to win, I had some disappointment, seeing as I was in support for John McCain.
But, you know, that quickly subsided, especially after hearing John McCain's concession speech.
He was very humble.
He was genuine in admitting defeat.
And, you know, he was just telling his supporters to transition in supporting the new president.
And that wasn't hard.
You know, it's not hard for me because I was never - never not liked Barack Obama, but it was extremely emotional, Barack Obama's speech.

I even choke up now just to think about how far, you know, how far America's gone, to think that just, you know, half a century ago, the African-American race wasn't respected very much, and to think that a black man is now in the most elite position in the United States is just absolutely amazing.
Do you know what you might write in your letter to President-elect Obama?
Not yet.
I'm don't - I'm not sure, but it's definitely going to be thank you for inspiring many people because a lot of doors are definitely going to open, and who knows what this is going to lead to.
Well, Heidi, thank you very much.
You're welcome.
That's Heidi Reyes, a 16-year-old junior at Blair High School.
We also heard from her classmate, Pooja Shah, and their history teacher, Alfredo Mathew.
It's Pride Month, and celebrations are happening all over the country, a lot of them also marking the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots, when New York police raided a gay bar.
The patrons resisted, and a movement was born.
Now there's a debate over whether to allow police officers in uniform to participate in Pride events.
Sally Schilling from Capital Public Radio in Sacramento reports.
Happy Pride.
Happy Pride.
The Pride parade featured rainbow flags, tutus, glitter and off-duty police officers.
Police Sergeant Michele Gigante was one of at least a dozen of them who marched in Sacramento's celebration yesterday.
So this is actually a really huge event for me as a - an out lesbian officer.
It's a fantastic day, and I'm so happy that we're able to march in uniform.
Gigante almost wasn't allowed to wear her badge this year.
Ten days ago, Sacramento Pride organizers decided to ban officers from participating in uniform to honor people who have been harmed by police.
Ebony Harper is a transgender activist in Sacramento.
She agreed with the decision.
She says police sometimes assume that all transgender people are sex workers.
It happened to her just a couple weeks ago.
I was stopped and asked for my ID.
And I said, no, I'm not giving you my ID.
And I said, I have a job.
You know, I'm well-known in this community.
But, you know, he still didn't believe me.
I don't know how they could be anything but public domain.
But according to the Smithsonian, I'm not allowed to use them without their specific permission.
That's Carl Malamud, an Internet activist who has challenged the Securities and Exchange Commission and C-Span over their online policies and won.
He says the Muybridge images are way too old to be protected by copyright, but Malamud says he had to get the Smithsonian's permission and paid $200 before he could download a high-quality copy.
The whole point of the public domain is that it isn't owned by anybody.
You don't have to ask.
You can use it for anything.
Taking material in the public domain, pretending that it's property and telling people they can't use it is directly contrary to the mission of the Smithsonian.
To make his point, Malamud bought three high-quality images of Muybridge's contact sheets and posted them for anyone to use free on the Internet earlier this month.
People who use these images in films or books should have to pay for them, Smithsonian official say, because scanning is expensive.
Linda St. Thomas is a spokesperson for the Smithsonian.
Ms.
LINDA St. THOMAS (Spokesperson, Smithsonian Institution): Our goal is to be very open about our photographs, although we cannot afford to offer high-resolution photographs to everyone who asks.
St.
Thomas points out that the Smithsonian does make lower resolution versions of these images available for free, but Malamud says the quality is too low.
And he objects to restrictions the Smithsonian places on how the images can be use, so Malamud posted more than 6,000 of those images on the Web, too, without the institution's warnings.
The kinds of warnings that, let's say, you can use it but, if you do any of these things, it's not okay.
And it's the kind of warning that if a kid goes to a teacher, and says can I use this on my report?
The teacher will probably look at those and say, hmm, let's go look some place else for some material for your report.
The institution's Web site says the Smithsonian quote, ""specifically retains any rights including possible copyright,"" which it may have in these files.
Spokesperson Linda St. Thomas says it's rare for the institution to deny permission for a commercial use of these images though it has happened.
Ms.
St. THOMAS: We wouldn't want a photograph being use in a - I don't know, pornography publication or something.
We are not monitoring things.
We just want to make sure that it's appropriate use of Smithsonian resources.
This isn't the first time a Smithsonian business venture has been criticized for trying to make money from the institution's collections.
Earlier this year, filmmakers denounced the Smithsonian's semi-exclusive deal with the cable channel Showtime.

Like the Smithsonian, the Library of Congress gets the majority of its funding from the federal government but the Library is taking a very different approach to the prints and photographs it makes available online.
Spokesman Matt Raymond says more than one million digital images are available for free, no questions asked.

We were established by Congress as a universal repository of human creativity and knowledge, and that includes vast amounts of items that are in the public domain and it is our mission to make those freely accessible whether in the 21 reading rooms of the Library of Congress or online.
